course.subject: ECON
course.name: Managerial Microeconomics
course.description: Demand estimation, business and economic forecasting; production, innovation and cost; market structure, strategic behavior and pricing; decision making under uncertainty; government regulation of business activities; case studies.
course.prerequisites: One of ECON 2103 OR ECON 2113
course.exclusions: ECON 3113, ECON 3133

reviews.author: Dreamscometrue
reviews.comment_content:
Choices and preferences
Economics of information
Basics of Market
Oligopoly (game theory)
Types of oligopoly
Endogenous sunk costs.
Product differentiation
Pricing strategies
What is market?

The content is very interesting and challenging. These all provides a new view of economics, but not just pure extension of introductory micro.

For mathematics usage, mostly we use partial differentiation and lagrange multiplier. No proofs are needed, basically you just need to know how to carry out those procedures.

Textbooks are not necessary as they are too easy. Half of the content are not from the book.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor teaching is great. He illustrates all the concept clearly. When there is mathematical derivation, he will show us how to carry out those steps (although sometimes he made careless mistakes).

Wing stresses on the importance of economic logic. He mentioned that math is a tool for us to understand economics, it is a help rather than torture. In fact, at this level, it is really true. Using math can make most things easier.

One thing that may not be great is that professor always forgot to upload slides, we can just listen and jot on blank papers. But not matter much!
reviews.comment_grading:
10% PS
20% Essay
30% midterm
40% final

Most students can get full marks in PS.

Mean for the other parts are roughly 70%-75% (exams are easier than last semester)

Scoring above more than mean 1sd will give you an A+. Good grading indeed.
reviews.comment_workload:
Just revise materials for exams, understand but not memorise.

Problem sets are textbook questions, will not be graded too harshly.

Writing project is the most difficult part. You have to think of a topic and explain the phenomenon using economics concept.

reviews.author: Hurr
reviews.comment_content: USE THE TEXTBOOK. Wing's PPTs are not detailed- many of them simple have a graph with absolutely no explanation. As is, the topics are not that difficult. If you use the textbook, you will have a good grasp of the concepts. And personally, I found them interesting because it introduces more depth into topics that I have not done before. BUT this is clearly a scam. Refer to Grading.
reviews.comment_teaching: The 'D' is not a reflection of Wing's personality. He's a great guy, pretty funny and talks about interesting topics. Its just that the topics are not relevant to the course. Most of the lesson is spent on real world examples which just turn to a sermon on life lessons. He claims that the key to getting good grades on the exams is attending all the lectures, but I find that hard to believe. I attended all classes before mid-term and still got a shitty grade. So I stopped attending lectures after that because it was a waste of time and used that time for other courses, or just for studying the content from the textbook.
reviews.comment_grading: Pretty harsh I would say. Its just that, even if you have a good understanding of what is given in the textbook, and you do well in the weekly problem sets, you will BOMB the exams. Wing sets really tough exam papers that evoke laughter and tears. Laughter because it seems like a joke because the type of questions he sets have seemingly NO connection to what the course actually covers, and tears because you know you're dead.
reviews.comment_workload: Pretty fair workload. 1 problem set (end of chapter questions from the textbook) almost every week. 1 mid-term, 1 final, and 1 written assignment of 1000 words that is due in the final exam study break.

Chp1 - Chp4(I)

reviews.comment_workload:
Problem sets have nearly no workload. You can finish each of them in an hour if you understand the concepts clearly.
The writing assignment requires you to write an essay that explains something with economic models/theories. You can choose whatever topic you want. Remember not to include too many models/equations/theories/data/references. Prof Siu focuses on how you explain the phenomenon and the logic behind it. The word limit is 1000.

reviews.author: Oscar Yu
reviews.comment_content: The contents presented in the class were notably challenging, requiring a significant amount of mental effort and concentration to comprehend. The complexity of the subject matter demanded heightened focus and attentiveness in order to grasp the intricacies involved. Additionally, it is important to acknowledge that the content covered in class may undergo modifications or adjustments based on the teaching pace, which can further impact the level of difficulty for students. Adapting to these potential changes necessitates flexibility and the ability to quickly adapt one's learning strategies to effectively keep up with the shifting pace and evolving content.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching approach employed in the economics class was highly commendable, particularly for those with a keen interest in the subject. The instructor skillfully crafted engaging and captivating lessons that captured the attention of the students. Notably, the teacher began each session by reviewing and reinforcing the content covered in the previous lecture, ensuring a solid foundation for further learning. This deliberate repetition served as a helpful refresher, allowing students to consolidate their understanding and bridge any knowledge gaps. As the class progressed, the level of difficulty was gradually increased, providing a gradual and seamless transition from familiar concepts to more complex ones. This incremental approach to content delivery enabled students to build upon their existing knowledge and tackle more challenging topics with confidence. Overall, the combination of an engaging teaching style, thoughtful review sessions, and a gradual increase in difficulty contributed to an enriching and rewarding learning experience in the economics class.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading system implemented in the course was designed to ensure fairness and provide support for hard-working students. It recognized and rewarded diligent effort, giving due credit to those who consistently demonstrated dedication to their studies. The evaluation criteria were structured in a manner that offered protection and encouragement for students who put in significant work. To succeed in the course, a recommended level of understanding was set at a minimum of 80% of the content.
reviews.comment_workload: The course had a remarkably light workload, which was a notable advantage for students. The workload was carefully balanced and manageable, allowing students to effectively allocate their time and energy across multiple courses or commitments.

reviews.author: Justin Lo
reviews.comment_content: The syllabus is very interesting even for non-economics major students. Although the concepts and formulas can seem challenging at first glance, when contextualized and slowly explained with examples, it is really interesting and opens lots of new perspectives on using mathematics for solving economics problems. The tutorials are also helpful for reminding us about the basic maths concepts, so don't worry even if you're rusty. I recommend this course even if you don't major in economics, if you're from the business faculty or IPO.
reviews.comment_teaching: Siu Kam Wing is a nice teacher with a good voice and articulation, a good sense of humor and is good at keeping the class interesting. He is very willing to slow down to let students think and absorb the lesson contents. One of the best teachers I've had so far
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is fair, but make sure to double check answers with the TAs, as I have experience with them marking incorrectly. There are people that get full marks on midterms, so it's not too difficult if you pay attention to lectures and review. There is very low variance in in-class performance so it really depends on midterms to draw the skill level bell curve, but its not hard
reviews.comment_workload: Getting full marks on homework assignments is easy. Some reviewing after class will be needed, but there's no groupwork, only an individual freestyle essay using economics concepts, and the midterms and finals

reviews.author: Gayauuuu
reviews.title: BEST Professor in Teaching!!!
reviews.comment_content:
1) The Theory of Individual Behaviour
2) Individual Choice Under Uncertainty
3) Economics of Information
4) Organization of Firm
5) Game Theory
6) Oligopoly Models
7) Pricing Strategies

The final is cumulative. It is basically an advanced level of Econ 2113 or 2103. Compared to other business courses, it requires quite a lot of math, typically differentiation. But the professor loves to use intuition to better explain the concepts after using math, so don't be too worried if you are suck at calculation.

In the mid-term and final, you will not encounter many math problems. However, the crux is still the intuitions and the logic behind the concepts, so make sure you know and digest all the contents well before the exams, and you will not get a bad grade for sure!
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Siu is excellent at teaching. I cannot say his accent is native or fluent. But he can always explain all concepts clearly with his Hong Kong accent.

He's also an interesting professor. He loves to share his own
experience during classes (e.g. dating experience), which makes the interaction of the class vivid. He is patient in answering questions as well, be it in class or via email. I would say he is the BEST professor that I have faced in university!

But one thing you should be careful about, especially during online lessons/exams. He only gave us 3 minutes to scan our answers during mid-term, when everyone had around 10 pages to scan. After complaints, he raised the scanning time to 5 minutes during the final, which is not really sufficient as well...

I eventually got an A+.
My score:
Problem Set: Full
Writing Assignment: 82/100

Final: 78/100 (~+1.5sd)

Maybe due to online exams, the exams are SUPER long compared to other semesters. Most people did not have enough time to complete the exams, given the difficulty of the questions was not really hard.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is very light, with only 5 problem sets (graded by effort) and a piece of 1000 words writing assignment.

You can easily finish the problem set within an hour and the writing assignment within 5-6 hours. The deadline for the writing assignment is the last day of the final study break, so it's very easy to manage your time.

reviews.author: Oscar Wong
reviews.title: Good course if you are interested in Econ
reviews.comment_content:
1.  Mathematics review
2.  Individual Behavior and Market Demand
3.  Individual Behavior under Uncertainty
4.  Economics of Information
5.  The Organization of the Firm
6.  Market and Market Failure
7.  Game Theory
8.  Market Structure and Competitive Analysis
10. Pricing Strategies for Firms with Market Power

All are basic to intermediate micro economics.  If you really pay attention during lectures, you will not have major difficulties.  This semester also includes the mathematics review for those who really have no idea what is differentiation.  This helps students who have poor maths background to understand the upcoming economic concepts.
reviews.comment_teaching: Wing is a funny professor.  He shared quite a lot of his personal experience during lectures.  I am not saying that those are useless, but I would suggest him spend more time discussing the details.  For some topics I found his explanations not quite enough and I need to have private bookings with him to clarify the details.

10% problem set
20% writing assignment
25% mid term
45% final

Problem set you just need to submit it on time.  TA will not mark it.  Submission=full mark
Writing assignment no score released.
Mid term and final are all long questions, no MC.

Mid term 86, mean 81, median 85, SD 13
Final 91, mean 62, median 64.5, SD 18.8
Final grade A+
reviews.comment_workload: Little workload.  Problem set you can just submit a blank document if you really don't have time.  But of course strongly encourage you to finish the questions afterwards because they are similar to final and mid term.  Writing assignment max 1000 words also not a big deal.  So all remains is paying attention during lectures and regular study.  Since the topics are not that difficult in my opinion and wing explains it quite well, studying shall not take a lot of time.

reviews.comment_content: The covered materials are a bit more advanced than the Intro MicroEcon and covers a wide variety of topics. But overall, they're still understandable and interesting even for a non-business major like me.
reviews.comment_teaching: SIU Kam Wing is generally a nice guy. He's knowledgeable regarding real-world problems and issues but tends to rattle on abt useless stuff sometimes. He's willing to answer questions and often goes off the material to cover more interesting aspects of the topic.
reviews.comment_grading: His midterms and finals are essay/problem solving types. So need to really read and analyze his slides because SIU Kam Wing tends to skip lecture slides. I found that having textbook was really helpful for studying.

8 problem sets from the textbook. There was also a 1000-word essay which was really challenging but fun as you get to explore everyday topics through an economic perspective.

The tutorials just cover problem sets from the textbook, attendance doesn't really make that much of a difference.
